page.title: 16THE RHUM MIDGE
page.content: Rhum midges have a strange effect on most people! From around June until September they stop many people from gardening, fishing, hill climbing, and many other outdoor activities! They stop people from even venturing out when they are really out in force. The female midges lay several hundred eggs in water in a mass of jelly which attaches to something solid. The eggs hatch into larvae and these swim quite freely, but later, they settle in the mud. Midges live by sucking the blood of animals, birds and insects. They also bite humans! They cause irritation when they bite as they pump saliva into their victim to thin the blood before sucking it. They are about 2mm long. They are at their worst during warm, still weather in the evenings.
